examples:
• Apa (monkey)
• Ananas (pineapple)
• Arbete (work)
• Alltid (always)
• Att (to/that)
notes:
Letter name: 'ah'
Pronunciation: /ɑː/ (like 'a' in father)
One of the most common vowels in Swedish

examples:
• Boll (ball)
• Barn (child)
• Bok (book)
• Blå (blue)
• Börja (to begin)
notes:
Letter name: 'beh'
Pronunciation: /b/ (same as English)
Always pronounced the same way

examples:
• Cykel (bicycle)
• Citron (lemon)
• Centrum (center)
• Cirka (circa/about)
• Cell (cell)
notes:
Letter name: 'seh'
Pronunciation: /s/ before e, i, y (soft)
              /k/ before a, o, u (hard)
Mostly appears in loanwords

examples:
• Dörr (door)
• Dag (day)
• Dansa (to dance)
• Dricka (to drink)
• Du (you)
notes:
Letter name: 'deh'
Pronunciation: /d/ (same as English)
Always pronounced the same way

examples:
• Elefant (elephant)
• Ett (one/a)
• Eld (fire)
• Efter (after)
• Exempel (example)
notes:
Letter name: 'eh'
Pronunciation: /eː/ (long) or /ɛ/ (short)
The most common letter in Swedish

examples:
• Fisk (fish)
• Familj (family)
• Fem (five)
• Fråga (to ask)
• Förstå (to understand)
notes:
Letter name: 'eff'
Pronunciation: /f/ (same as English)
Always pronounced the same way

examples:
• Gata (street) - hard g
• Glass (ice cream) - hard g
• Göra (to do) - soft g
• Gärna (gladly) - soft g
• Gymnastik (gymnastics) - soft g
notes:
Letter name: 'geh'
Pronunciation: /g/ (hard) before a, o, u, å
              /j/ (like 'y' in yes) before e, i, y, ä, ö

examples:
• Hus (house)
• Hej (hello)
• Hand (hand)
• Hjälp (help)
• Höra (to hear)
notes:
Letter name: 'haw'
Pronunciation: /h/ (same as English)
Silent in 'hj', 'lj', 'dj' combinations

examples:
• Is (ice)
• Inte (not)
• Idag (today)
• Innan (before)
• Ibland (sometimes)
notes:
Letter name: 'ee'
Pronunciation: /iː/ (like 'ee' in see)
Always pronounced as a long 'ee' sound

examples:
• Ja (yes)
• Jul (Christmas)
• Jobb (job)
• Jorden (Earth)
• Jämför (compare)
notes:
Letter name: 'jee'
Pronunciation: /j/ (like 'y' in yes)
Never pronounced like English 'j'

examples:
• Katt (cat) - hard k
• Kaffe (coffee) - hard k
• Kök (kitchen) - soft k
• Kär (dear) - soft k
• Kyrka (church) - soft k
notes:
Letter name: 'kaw'
Pronunciation: /k/ (hard) before a, o, u, å
              /ɕ/ (soft, like 'sh') before e, i, y, ä, ö

examples:
• Lampa (lamp)
• Liten (small)
• Läsa (to read)
• Lära (to learn)
• Ljus (light)
notes:
Letter name: 'ell'
Pronunciation: /l/ (same as English)
'lj' makes a 'y' sound in some dialects

examples:
• Mus (mouse)
• Mamma (mom)
• Mat (food)
• Mycket (much/very)
• Morgon (morning)
notes:
Letter name: 'emm'
Pronunciation: /m/ (same as English)
Always pronounced the same way

examples:
• Natt (night)
• Nej (no)
• Namn (name)
• Ny (new)
• Någon (someone)
notes:
Letter name: 'enn'
Pronunciation: /n/ (same as English)
Always pronounced the same way

examples:
• Ord (word)
• Och (and)
• Ost (cheese)
• Ofta (often)
• Omkring (around)
notes:
Letter name: 'oo'
Pronunciation: /uː/ (like 'oo' in food) or /ɔ/ (short)
Can have different sounds depending on length

examples:
• Penna (pen)
• Pappa (dad)
• Pengar (money)
• Prova (to try)
• På (on)
notes:
Letter name: 'peh'
Pronunciation: /p/ (same as English)
Always pronounced the same way

examples:
• Qatar (Qatar)
• Quiche (quiche)
• Quiz (quiz)
• Quinoa (quinoa)
• Quattro (four - Italian)
notes:
Letter name: 'koo'
Pronunciation: /k/
Extremely rare - only in foreign words

examples:
• Ros (rose)
• Röd (red)
• Resa (trip)
• Rätt (right/correct)
• Ringa (to call)
notes:
Letter name: 'err'
Pronunciation: /r/ (rolled or tapped)
Varies by dialect - can be rolled, tapped, or guttural

examples:
• Sol (sun)
• Sitta (to sit)
• Sverige (Sweden)
• Ska (shall/will)
• Stor (big)
notes:
Letter name: 'ess'
Pronunciation: /s/ (same as English)
'sk' before e, i, y, ä, ö makes 'sh' sound

examples:
• Träd (tree)
• Tack (thanks)
• Tid (time)
• Tala (to speak)
• Tillsammans (together)
notes:
Letter name: 'teh'
Pronunciation: /t/ (same as English)
'tj' makes a 'sh' sound

examples:
• Uggla (owl)
• Under (under)
• Ute (outside)
• Upp (up)
• Utan (without)
notes:
Letter name: 'oo'
Pronunciation: /ʉː/ (like 'oo' with rounded lips)
More rounded than English 'oo'

examples:
• Vatten (water)
• Vän (friend)
• Vit (white)
• Varför (why)
• Vecka (week)
notes:
Letter name: 'veh'
Pronunciation: /v/ (same as English)
Very common letter in Swedish

examples:
• Wigge (name)
• Wennerberg (surname)
• Wiklund (surname)
• Wilhelm (name)
• Wienerkorv (Vienna sausage)
notes:
Letter name: 'dubbel-ve' (double-v)
Pronunciation: /v/ (same as V)
Very rare - only in names and some loanwords. Modern Swedish uses V instead

examples:
• Xylofon (xylophone)
• X-ray (x-ray)
• Taxi (taxi)
• Extra (extra)
• Exempel (example - sometimes spelled with x)
notes:
Letter name: 'eks'
Pronunciation: /ks/
Rare letter - mostly in loanwords

examples:
• Yrke (profession)
• Ny (new)
• Syster (sister)
• Fyra (four)
• Mycket (much/very)
notes:
Letter name: 'y'
Pronunciation: /yː/ (like German 'ü' or French 'u')
Unique sound - rounded lips while saying 'ee'

examples:
• Zoo (zoo)
• Zebra (zebra)
• Zon (zone)
• Zink (zinc)
• Zigzag (zigzag)
notes:
Letter name: 'zäta'
Pronunciation: /s/
Very rare - mostly in loanwords, often replaced with 's'

examples:
• År (year)
• Åtta (eight)
• Åska (thunder)
• Också (also)
• Språk (language)
notes:
Letter name: 'å'
Pronunciation: /oː/ (like 'aw' in law)
27th letter in Swedish alphabet

examples:
• Äpple (apple)
• Äta (to eat)
• Kär (dear/in love)
• Väder (weather)
• Lära (to learn)
notes:
Letter name: 'ä'
Pronunciation: /ɛː/ (like 'ai' in air)
28th letter in Swedish alphabet

examples:
• Öga (eye)
• Öppna (to open)
• Hör (hear)
• Kött (meat)
• Förstå (to understand)
notes:
Letter name: 'ö'
Pronunciation: /øː/ (like 'ur' in fur, without the 'r')
29th letter in Swedish alphabet
